前幾個星期扭親左手手腕 想做都做唔到。
黎緊依兩個月應該都係啞鈴操腳/練腹，跑。

但係講真如果唔係飲奶粉，每日食夠100-120g響開始果個星期係ok，但係長期真係好難做到.....計落會食好多嘢，一日三幾餐會好貴

而且無d人話會肚子餓...因為你隔三個幾鐘又食d高蛋白質既嘢落肚，d高蛋白質既嘢又勁飽肚...定係我食錯..（麥片、全麥麵包、雞胸、牛肉、魚，蝦等等..）
我依家日食70-90g已經ok飽每日，如果仲要食多d咪日日飽死 食到會嘔wor......

重點，其實我無乜肌肉量 我係做緊先減脂後增肌肌步驟..開始左一個月。有keep住做啞鈴健身，因為未有市政gym卡申請緊。想話用依個月做適應期，應該可以增肌減脂同時進行掛
如果我係依個狀態，70-90g蛋白質日食都未夠咩

有冇餐單分享下



新仔分享：
早餐：麥皮+兩塊全麥麵包夾花生/果醬+烚蛋x1連蛋黃+豆漿一杯

午餐：雞胸x1+煎蛋x1+少少菜

晚餐：雞胸x1/魚x2～3+蝦仁炒西蘭花
/蒸蛋（蛋x3）+少少其他（老母煮佢自己既咸送）

零食：有時食包蛋糕仔/乳酪一杯/豆腐花

其實我咁食已經好飽 好少話有餓感，雖然有時會突然勁肚餓，基本上未餓已經又下一餐。

或者你可以上斜bench press superset 窄手/下斜掌上壓


Superset姐係點操法？

兩個動作連住做，中間無休息
bench press>>>>push up ，跟住先休息
superset亦係我常用嘅訓練方式


其實Superset唔係用同一組肌肉做兩個動作，係將主動再非主動果兩部分肌肉交換咁練，例如你推胸，背肌其係要收緊用力hold住，咁當練完胸肌，就掉轉練上背，又或者二三頭互換，所以superset做緊兩個動作，練緊同樣兩舊肌肉，不過主動同被動不斷交換
而你果種係類似練至力竭，增加下數黎產生代謝壓力
兩種方法都係短時間大量消耗體力，新手就唔建議做啦

其實Superset唔係用同一組肌肉做兩個動作，係將主動再非主動果兩部分肌肉交換咁練，例如你推胸，背肌其係要收緊用力hold住，咁當練完胸肌，就掉轉練上背，又或者二三頭互換，所以superset做緊兩個動作，練緊同樣兩舊肌肉，不過主動同被動不斷交換
而你果種係類似練至力竭，增加下數黎產生代謝壓力
兩種方法都係短時間大量消耗體力，新手就唔建議做啦

superset亦係我常用嘅訓練方式


其實Superset唔係用同一組肌肉做兩個動作，係將主動再非主動果兩部分肌肉交換咁練，例如你推胸，背肌其係要收緊用力hold住，咁當練完胸肌，就掉轉練上背，又或者二三頭互換，所以superset做緊兩個動作，練緊同樣兩舊肌肉，不過主動同被動不斷交換
而你果種係類似練至力竭，增加下數黎產生代謝壓力

superset泛指兩個動作連住做，唔一定要對抗肌群架


Superset喺外國已經定義左針對對抗肌群好耐㗎啦，你果種已經偏向左去giant set（唔同動作去操同一位置）
好多人都搞唔清楚super set ，drop set 同giant set
Superset本身只係想慳時間同令到對抗肌平衡啲，仲可以強化埋心肺，好多人都唔會點休息，superset其實都要抖30秒左右，原因係如果選擇嘅重量合適，唔抖就做唔返果個重量，假設胸做完，停30秒，背做完抖30秒，呢個時候胸已經抖左一分鐘，所以兩個動作就可以不停咁做，喺superset個過程，由於組與組之間個休息時間好短，心跳會保持偏高直至做完全部動作，所以慳時間之餘對卡路里消耗都比較高
Drop set就係無休息咁用同一個動作遞減重量去練一個位置，目的就係將果舊肌肉揸乾揸淨，快慢肌一齊練，即係類似全力跑完100，慢啲跑200，再慢跑多400
Giant set就類似你果種用唔同動作去練一個部分，唔同嘅係呢個set通常有4個或以上動作，例如練背果日，做完barbell row即刻或者抖10秒左右做引體上升，再做個deadlift,同玩 cable,跟著抖耐少少再重複
我唔係想踩你台，不過唔同練法個宗旨係好唔同，所以真係要搞清楚

胸+三頭既好處就係做胸個陣三頭係輔助肌肉
做完胸再做幾個三頭動作就可以以工
背+二頭同理

一開始企遠啲＞跳上槓＞係fing返返轉頭嘅時候做爆發引體＞將膝頭引向心口（kipping）＞轉手＞直bar dip撐起身。

對upright row冇意見
純粹覺得你個logic好搞笑

地動說

The Upright Row exercise is done to develop the shoulders and traps. Holding a barbell or dumbells in front of your with a close, overhand grip, you pull the weight up to your chest, keeping it close to your body, leading with your elbows.

The Upright Row is one of the most harmful exercises you can expose your shoulders to. The problem with the exercise lies in the position your arms must be in in order to perform the movement. This position is called "internal rotation."

To demonstrate internal rotation, hold your arms straight out to the sides with your palms down. Now rotate your hands forward as if you were pouring out a glass of water in each. To do the upright row, the arms are bent at the elbow then internally rotated.

Internal rotation itself is not necessarily bad for your shoulders. The problem comes when you raise the arms up and add resistance in that position. Every time you raise the weight, a small tendon in your shoulder gets pinched (known as impingement) by the bones in the shoulder.

This may not hurt immediately; it may not even hurt for a long, long time. The problem is the tendon will gradually become worn down and damaged. You may not even know you have a problem until one day the tendon snaps!

來源：https://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/betteru26.htm

Upright Rows: Shoulder Wrecker Or The Most Underrated Deltoid Exercise?

By Tom Venuto

Hey Tom, I was curious to hear what you think about barbell upright rows. I've been given conflicting information about this exercise. My personal trainer says that upright rows wreck your shoulders and you should never, ever do them, but I've heard from more than one bodybuilder in my gym who says that it's one of the best exercises for building up your deltoids and making your shoulders look wider. What's your take?


A: There are a lot of trainers, including highly educated ones, who habitually make all or nothing judgements of various exercises. With all due respect to your trainer and other trainers like him, I think the "all or nothing" attitude is not the ideal approach to exercise prescription.

An exercise should rarely if ever be judged as do it or don't do it. I prefer assigning a risk to benefit ratio to each exercise and saying things like, "it's riskier, so if you do it, do it with caution" instead of saying, "never do it."

The risk to benefit ratio of an exercise may be different for each person depending on whether you have any pre-existing orthopedic conditions like known impingement syndrome or rotator cuff injury. If you do, you may choose not to do the exercise at all. If you choose to proceed with the exercise, you should learn about and practice the modifications in form that reduce your risk of aggravating the injury further.

Whether you've been formally diagnosed with an injury or not, your decision to proceed with an exercise may also depend on whether it causes you any pain. Shoulder pain is extremely common. In one survey presented at the National Strength and Conditioning Association conference, 61% of recreational weight trainers said they experienced shoulder pain during weight training in the last year and 33% had shoulder pain during the last 30 days.

The general rule is that if it hurts, don't do it. Pushing through "bad pain" (as opposed to the "good pain" associated with the burn or fatigue of training) is an invitation to more pain or serious injury. However, many people exclude exercises that cause them no pain simply because they have been deemed "unsafe" by their trainer or they continue with exercises that cause them pain simply because the exercise has been deemed "safe" by their trainer and they think they should "tough it out."


One thing you want to avoid at all costs is causing an injury or new pain where it didn't exist before, as a result of bad judgement in exercise choice or poor exercise performance.

The upright row is a very popular bodybuilding exercise because it has a reputation for building the middle (lateral) deltoids very well with good secondary emphasis on the trapezius muscles. It's those lateral deltoids that make the shoulders wider, which is why exercises that overload the lateral head of the deltoid muscle are so valuable to the bodybuilder. In addition, the upright rowing motion is an integral part of power exercises including the clean and the clean and jerk. However, the upright row has come into question about whether it could cause an injury to a healthy shoulder.

There are two general grips used on an upright row - the narrow grip upright row and the wide grip upright row. The narrow grip variation is the one that has come under the most scrutiny. In fact, many strength coaches don't even call a wide grip upright row an upright row at all- they call it a high pull and consider it a different exercise. The power clean exercise and the clean and jerk both contain an explosive high pull segment in the exercise, but you rarely hear any trainers or coaches express undue concern about shoulder injury from those exercises.

The biggest concern from trainers and from sports medicine doctors or physio-therapists is a subacromial impingement as a result of full range narrow grip upright rows. That's because a full range of motion upright row requires you to pull the weight above shoulder level (90 degrees) with your arms in an internally rotated position. This could directly cause impingement or aggravate existing impingement. This subject has been well-studied with results published in numerous sports medicine, physical therapy and strength and conditioning journals. The good news is, experts say there are many ways to modify the form on the upright row to reduce the risk.

1. To reduce risk, pull only to shoulder level.

The most common advice you hear on proper form for weight lifting is to perform each exercise through the full range of motion. During the upright row however, the higher you pull (above shoulder level, ie, pulling the bar to the chin or nose or higher), the greater the impingement in the rotator cuff muscles. To reduce the risk, do not pull all the way up. Stop when your arms are shoulder level or parallell to the ground (90 degrees). People with pre-existing injuries will often feel the pain increase as they pull to the very top. If you feel lifting into a certain range of motion increase pain, reduce the range of motion and continue doing the exercise only in the pain-free zone.


2. To reduce the risk, reduce the poundage and perform the exercise more strictly.

Heavier training gives you greater benefits for strength development, but also increases the risk of injury. This is true for all exercises, but especially exercises with inherently high risks due to the exercise's biomechanics. Some good news for bodybuilders and people who want wider shoulders is that hypertrophy training doesn't require very heavy loads. The optimal hypertrophy range is an 8-12 rep max. If you want to reduce the risk on this exercise, don't use super heavy weights in the low rep ranges and never use heavier weights at the expense of strict form. Upright rows are not the type of exercise to max out on. In fact, many champion bodybuilders perform the exercise slowly with ultra strict form intentionally so they can stimulate the muscle without needing as much weight.


3. To reduce the risk, use progressive resistance slowly and use alternate methods of progressive overload.

Many people are so intent on adding weight to the bar, they rush the process and increase the load prematurely. Typically, this causes deterioration in form, or forces them to lower their rep range below the ideal hypertrophy range. To reduce risk, it's important to add weight slowly, only when you can perform the exercise in the designated hypertophy range with perfect form. Alternately, other forms of progression can be used such as increasing density (work per unit of time) instead of increasing poundage.

4. To reduce the risk, warm up thoroughly and consider performing the exercise last.

4. To reduce the risk, warm up thoroughly and consider performing the exercise last.

The degree to which pre-workout warmup might reduce injury is still debated, but in my opinion, it's common sense and all my personal experience confirms it. When I use the generic term "warm up" I'm including not only the literal warm up, referring to increased body temperature but also having performed some mobility exercises (arm circles, etc) before lifting. It also may help to perform the exercise last, since you won't be doing the exercise for strength but for hypertrophy. At the end of your workout, your strength will not be as high, but that means you won't need as much weight and your shoulders will be fully warmed up and have plenty of blood in the muscles.

5. To reduce the risk, try a wider grip.

The upright row is traditionally performed with a narrow grip, but if you experience any pain or want to reduce the risk of developing pain, try the upright row with a wider grip, also known as a high pull. Although the high pull is often used in power training, bodybuilders often use the wide grip upright row with a slower, controlled tempo for hypertrophy goals. You may find that the wider grip reduces pain or discomfort you were feeling with a narrow grip. Try dumbbells as well. The dumbbells not only allow for either a narrow or wide grip, they also allow unrestricted range of movement. Cables provide yet another option.

It's true that the risk of impingement, pain or injury from the upright row exercise is higher, but there may be a place for it in your training program if you have no pre-existing shoulder injuries and if deltoid development is a high priority for you. The upright row can do a great job on the lateral head of the deltoid, giving you that much-desired "cap on the shoulders" look. Keep the bar close to your body if you want maximum emphasis on that lateral deltoid.

This is only my personal experience, but I've been doing upright rows on and off since I was a teenager and I've never had any serious or chronic shoulder problems. I have however, felt pain temporarily in the past when my ego got in the way and I tried to see how much weight I could lift.

My advice is, If you have a shoulder injury, take a pass on the close grip upright rows. If you do them, don't do them as a heavy strength exercise. Forget about how much weight you can lift. Do the opposite: Find ways to make the exercise stricter and harder with less weight, such as 3 second holds at the top, slow negatives, drop sets, supersets, density training and constant tension. Put your mind into the muscle and feel it contract.

I don't believe there are many exercises you should "never do." But I do believe you should never do any exercise through bad pain or take unnecessary risks when you are injured or prone to injury. Train hard, train smart and remember there are thousands of different exercises to choose from, so don't get bent out of shape if you feel you should exclude an exercise. Just pick another one.



References

Baltaci G, Subacromial impingement syndrome in athletes: Prevention and exercise programs. Acta orthop traumat Turc, 37: 128-238, 2003..

Basford JR, Weightlifting, weight training and injuries. orthopedics, 8: 1051-1056. 1985.

Brossoman J et al, shoulder impingement syndrome: Influence of shoulder position on rotator cuff impingement - an anatomic study, AJR Am J Roentgenol, 167: 1511-1515, 1996.

Cibrario M, Preventing weight room rotator cuff tendonitis: A guide to muscular balance, Strength Cond Jour, 19: 22-25. 1997.

Durall CJ, et al, Avoiding shoulder injury from resistance training. Strength Cond Jour, 23: 10-18. 2001

Graichen H et al, subacromial space width changes during abduction and rotation - a 3-D MRI study, Durg Radiol Anat, 21: 59-64, 1999.

Gross ML, anterior shoulder instability in weight lifters. Am J Sports Med, 21: 599-603, 1993

Kuhn JE, Exericse in the treatment of rotator cuff impingement: A systematic review and a synthesized evidence-based rehabilitation protocol. J Shoulder Elbow Surg, 18: 138-160, 2009.

Schoenfeld B et al, Implications for preventing subacromial impingement, Strength and Conditioning Journal, 33(5), 25-28. Department of Exercise Science, Lehman college, New York.

Yu J, Common injuries related to weightlifting: MRI perspective, sem musculoskeletal radiol, 9: 289-301, 2005.

其實gym中間拉筋都有幫助
因為肌肉唔知你舉幾重，動作之間休息時拉筋除左令肌肉產生錯覺以為train緊
仲可以改善之後動作既range of motion


同埋點解大家有印象大隻佬就論盡，因爲以前唔知拉筋既重要
Build up肌肉同時唔鍛練返新長出黎既肌肉柔軟就會咁
事實上科學研究證實過肌肉唔會影響關節活動性（除非你係練到某部位極端地大）

你睇返boxing NBA 美足就明，肌肉係唔會令人變到亞咋，只係香港唔重視柔軟性既鍛練
大家唔會覺得拉筋同健身有關係咁
